description: From Middle English cran, from Old English cran (“crane”), from Proto-West Germanic *kran, from Proto-Germanic *kranô (“crane”), from Proto-Indo-European *gerh₂- (“to cry hoarsely”).
Cognate with Scots cran (“crane”), Dutch kraan (“crane”), German Kran (“crane”). The mechanical devices are named from their likeness to the bird.

entries.meaning: Any bird of the family Gruidae, large birds with long legs and a long neck which is extended during flight.
examples: Aquatic birds of various kinds are very numerous, such as geese, darters (Flotus melanogaster), scissor-bills (Rhynchops nigra), adjutants (Leptoptilos argala), pelicans, cormorants, cranes (Grus antigone, in Burmese gyoja), whimbrels, plovers, and ibises.

entries.meaning: (US, dialect) Ardea herodias, the great blue heron.
A mechanical lifting machine or device, often used for lifting heavy loads for industrial or construction purposes.
An iron arm with horizontal motion, attached to the side or back of a fireplace for supporting kettles etc. over the fire.
A siphon, or bent pipe, for drawing liquors out of a cask.
(nautical) A forked post or projecting bracket to support spars, etc.; generally used in pairs.

verbs.description: crane (third-person singular simple present cranes, present participle craning, simple past and past participle craned)

examples: and my bachelor's hearth is imbedded where by much craning of head and neck I can catch sight of a sycamore in the Square garden,

entries.meaning: (transitive) To raise or lower with, or as if with, a crane.
examples: an upstart craned up to the height he has

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To pull up before a jump.

description: From Middle English crane, cranee, from Old French cran, from Medieval Latin crānium.

entries.meaning: Alternative form of cran (“measure of herrings”)
